document.docAuthor: Sadeghi, Mehrdad Zamanpoore ı Yaser Bakhshi ı Saber & Malek-Hosseini, Mohammad Javad
document.docTitle: Niphargus keeleri Sadeghi & Malek-Hosseini 2020, sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: Niphargus keeleri n. sp. ı a new cave Amphipod (Arthropoda: Crustacea) from the Zagros Mountainsı Iran

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Niphargus keeleri n. sp. ı a new cave Amphipod (Arthropoda: Crustacea) from the Zagros Mountainsı Iran

mods:name.mods:namePart: Sadeghi, Mehrdad Zamanpoore ı Yaser Bakhshi ı Saber

subSubSection.paragraph:
Holotype .
Maleı body length 8 mmı October
2011ı
ZM-CBSU Amph 3418ı coll. M.J. Malek- Hosseinie and
Y. Bakhshi. Locus
typicus: Keeler springı Keeler Cave ( 31.283°Nı 50.583°N )ı Keeler Valleyı
140 km
north-west of Yasuj ( Kohgiluyeh and Boyerahmad Province ); altitude
1610 m
.
Paratypes : two males and one female; same date and localityı FAIC
112001
ı coll
. M .J. Malek-Hosseinie and Y. Bakhshi.
Allotypes : seven males and one femaleı July
2012ı
same localityı FAIC
112002
ı coll
. M .J. Malek-Hosseinie and Y. Bakhshi
. All specimens including type series are kept in the Aquatic Invertebrate Collection of the Museum of Fars Research Centre of Agriculture and Natural Resources ( FAIC )ı Shirazı Iran
.
The holotype is deposited in the Zoological Museum of the University of Shiraz ( ZM-CBSU )
.

This new species can be distinguished from other niphargid species by a combination of characters. These include long and slender pereopod III–VIIı no spine on dorsal surface of telsonı short second article of uropod III exopoditeı distinct irregular trapezoid palm of gnathopod IIı a row of 16 fine setae attached on inner margin of dactylus of gnathopods I and IIı not sharply pointed epimeral plates I–IIIı one spine on distal end of urosomite Iı long E-setae in third segment of mandible palpı pleopods I–III with long setaeı palmar corner of gnathopod I and II with 1–2 and 1 small spiniform setaeı respectively.

caption.paragraph:
Figure 1. Lateral view photograph of
Niphargus keeleri
sp. nov. , male paratype, 13 mm, from Keeler Cave, north-west of Yasuj, Iran.

subSubSection.paragraph: The new species is named after the type locality: Keeler Caveı Yasujı Iran .
The description is based on examination of the holotypeı and of two male and one female dissected paratypes .
Head and trunk. Body slenderı length up to 16 mm ( Figure 1 ). Head length up to ca 6% of body length; head with a short rostrum. Lateral cephalic lobes sub-rounded ( Figure 2 (e)).

Pleonites I–III. Smoothı epimeral plate I distal margin convexı epimeral plate II distal margin convexı with 2–3 short spinesı antero-distal corner convex; epimeral plate III postero-distal corner moderately pointedı distal margin straight to moderately convexı anterior distal corner convexı 2–3 short spines along ventral margin of epimeral plate II and III ( Figure 2 (b)).

caption.paragraph:
Figure 2.
Niphargus keeleri
sp. nov. , male holotype, 16 mm, from Keeler Cave, north-west of Yasuj, Iran: (a) urosomites, (b) pleonites, (c) antenna 1, (d) antenna II, (e) head capsule, (f) telson.

subSubSection.paragraph: Urosomites. Urosomite I with 1–2 very short setae at dorsolateral posterior marginı urosomite II–III with combination of 2–4 small spines and 1–2 short setae on each side. A spine is seen ventrodistally on urosomite I ( Figure 2 (a)).
Telson. Laminar deep cleftı moderately elongatedı distally narrower; length:width ratio 1.2; 3 apical spines in each lobeı of up to 0.35 of telson length ( Figure 2 (f)).

Antenna I. Long (0.5–0.65 of body length)ı main flagellum with 28–32 articles ( Figure 2 (c)); accessory flagellum biarticulate. Antennae I length is more than twice that of antenna IIı ca. 2.2 times.

Antenna II. Articles 4 and 5 with a few bundles of short setae (as long as the width of the article) on lateralı and a few longer on distal margin (almost twice longer than the width of the article). Length of peduncle article 5 slightly longer than article 4 (1.1–1.2); flagellum short (as long as ca. 0.4 length of peduncle articles 4 and 5)ı having 6 articles; gland cone short (reaching to 1/2 the length of article 3) and blunt ( Figure 2 (d)).

caption.paragraph:
Figure 3.
Niphargus keeleri
sp. nov. , male holotype, 16 mm, from Keeler Cave, north-west of Yasuj, Iran: (a) left mandible, (b) right mandible, (c) palp of right mandible, (d) maxilipede, (e) left maxilla I, (f) right maxilla I, (g) maxilla II, (h) labium.

Figure 4.
Niphargus keeleri
sp. nov. , male holotype, 16 mm, from Keeler Cave, north-west of Yasuj, Iran: (a) gnathopod I, (b) gnathopod II.

Figure 5.
Niphargus keeleri
sp. nov. , male holotype, 16 mm, from Keeler Cave, north-west of Yasuj, Iran: (a) pereopod III, (b) pereopod IV, (c) pereopod V, (d) pereopod VI, (e) pereopod VII.

subSubSection.paragraph: Mouthparts. Labrum slightly longer than broad; labium inner lobes well developedı as long as 2/3 of outer lobe ( Figure 3 (h)).

Maxilla I (left and right). Inner plate with 2–3 distal setae; outer plate with 7 toothed spines each with 0–3 strong lateral teeth; palp distal article with 2 long apical setaeı slightly shorter than or as long as the distal article ( Figure 3 (eıf)).
Maxilla II. Inner plate shorter and broader than outer; both with apical setaeı inner plate with 1 subapical seta ( Figure 3 (g)).

Maxilliped. Outer lobe shortı with 1–3 distal smooth-topped spines and 6 apical and 2 lateral setaeı inner plate with a row of smooth spines along inner margin extended to the distal margin; palp well developed; 3 small setae at base of nail ( Figure 3 (d)).

Left mandible. Incisor with 6 teeth of increasing sizeı lacinia mobilis bifurcate; a row of 8 serrated spines of similar lengths between lacinia mobilis and molar processı a bundle of a few fine seta at inner base of molar process ( Figure 3 (a)).
Right mandible . Incisor with 3 teethı lacinia mobilis bifurcate; a row of 8 serrated spines between lacinia mobilis and molar process ( Figure 3 (b)).

caption.paragraph:
Figure 6.
Niphargus keeleri
sp. nov. , male holotype, 16 mm, from Keeler Cave, north-west of Yasuj, Iran: (a) pleopod I, (b) pleopod II, (c) pleopod III, (d) uropod I, (e) uropod II, (f) uropod III.

subSubSection.paragraph: Mandible palp first article without setaı second article with 11 strong setaeı almost as long as article 3; article 3 subfalciformı with 19 D-setae along inner margin and 5 long Esetaeı 5 A-setaeı and 4 rows of B-setae (2-2-2-2) ( Figure 3 (c)).

Gnathopod I. Coxal plate trapezoidı slightly longer than broadı antero-ventral corner subrounded with 3 setaeı 1 seta at mid-ventral margin. Basis proximally narrowerı dilated at posterior 1/3ı with a row of 9 grouped long setae in anterior margin and 2 groups of 4 and 9 long setae at the dilation angleı 5 setae at postero-distal and 1 seta in antero-distal corner; carpus postero-proximally dilated with a bundle of setaeı ischium with a group of 6 setae at postero-distal cornerı merus posterior margin with a row of 11 setae with increasing lengthı and 2 long spines; carpus postero-distal and lateral margins with parallel rows of long setaeı a few short setae on anterior distal corner; propodus slightly longer than broadı with a row of 9 transverse groups of setae along posterior marginı palm convex with 1 strong palmar robust seta and 1–2 small spiniform setae; posterior margin with 10 rows of setae; anterodistal corner with 5 setae; a row of very short setae on palmar surface; dactylus reaches posterior margin of propodusı with 3 single median setae along outer and 16 setae along inner margin ( Figure 4 (a)).

Gnathopod II. Coxal plate quadrilateralı longer than broadı antero-ventral corner subroundedı 8 very short setae along antero-distal and ventral marginsı 1 single stouter seta at postero-ventral corner; basis 1.4 times longer than and more slender compared to gnathopod 1ı 1 long seta in proximal anterior margin and a group of 9 long setae at the dilation angle; ischium with 7–8 postero-distal setae; merus with 3 posterior submarginal setae; carpus as long as or slightly shorter than propodusı 2 parallel rows of long setae on posterodistal and lateral marginsı anterior distal corner with a few short setae; propodus irregular trapezoid quadrilateralı nearly as long as broadı with a row of 12 transverse groups of setae along posterior margin; palm convex with 1 strong palmar robust seta and 1 small spiniform seta; posterior margin with 12 rows of setae; antero-distal corner with 6–7 setae; groups of 1–3 setae on palmar surface; dactylus reaches posterior margin of propodusı with 2 single median setae along outer and 16 setae along inner margin ( Figure 4 (b)).

Pereopods III–IV. Pereopod III ( Figure 5 (a)) slightly shorter than IV ( Figure 5 (b)); dactyli III–IV short with a few dorsal simple setae and 1 tiny spine at nail base; ratios of the length of nail:dactylus and dactylus:propodus are 0.48 and 0.50 for pereopod IIIı and 0.49 and 0.51 for pereopod IV; basis longı the ratio of basis length to the whole appendage length is ca. 0.3 in pereopod III and IV; bases are subcircular in PIII and quadrilateral in PIV.

Pereopods V–VII. Length of pereopods V:VI:VII is 1:1.24:1.20; length of pereopod VII:body length: 0.6; bases length:width ratio of pereopods V–VII: 1:0.51ı 1:0.47ı 1:0.53; posterior margins in PV and PVI straightı slightly convex in pVIIı with 8–10ı 9–13 and 7–9 short simple setaeı respectively; postero-distal corners with small lobes; anterior margin with 6– 7 short robust setae; ischium in pereopods V–VII with developed postero-ventral lobe; propodus of pereopod VII as long as in pereopod VI; dactylus: propodus length in pereopod VII is 0.28; nail:total dactylus length 0.37. Dactyli V–VII with a single dorsal seta; single tiny spine at the base of nail ( Figure 5 (c–e)).
Pleopods. Pleopods I–III distally with 2-hooked retinacles at inner margin; rami of pleopods I–III with 13–17 articles each ( Figure 6 (a–c)).

Uropods. Uropod I peduncle with 4 dorso-lateral spines; peduncle with 3 spines on distal margin; endopod:exopod length 1:1.01; endopod with 2 lateral and 4 apical slender spines; exopod with 3 lateral single spinesı parallelı with 2 groups of 2 spines each; 4 apical spines ( Figure 6 (d). Uropod II endopod:exopod length 1:1.03; peduncle with 3 spines on distal margin; endopod with 2 lateral and 2–3 apical slender spines; exopod with 2 apical spines ( Figure 6 (e)).

Uropod III of moderate sizeı 0.2 of body length; peduncle with 1–3 apical spines and 1 setaı no lateral setae. Endopod shortı 0.4 of the protopod length; exopod proximal article with 5 groups of 4 spines along inner margin and 4 groups of 4 spines along outer margin; distal article length 0.1 of the proximalı distal article with 3 lateral setae and 2 very short apical setae ( Figure 6 (f)).
No significant sex differences were recognised and the female sample showed only a few dissimilarities with the male holotype and paratypes .

Antennae I main flagellum with 26 articles; antenna II article 4 has bundles of short setae (longer than the width of the article) on lateralı and still longer on distalı marginı length of peduncle article 5 slightly shorter than article 4ı flagellum having 6 articlesı longer than peduncle articles 4 and 5ı gland cone longer (longer than 1/2 the length of article 3); gnathopod I propodus as long as broad; and gnathopod II carpus not dilated posteriorly and having few setae.

This cave is almost straightı and about 1000 metres long. Its entrance is relatively large and contains no well inside. In rainy seasonsı Keeler Cave is filled with a large amount of water and the water comes streaming out of the caveı but in dry seasons (e.g. at the end of springı and in summer) there is only a small stream coming from a relatively large pool at the end of the caveı making several smaller pools of various sizes in some parts of the cave. The large pool at the end of the caveı with a maximum depth of about 150 cmı is a permanent poolı and the
Niphargus
specimens were collected from its edges. The floor and walls of the cave are always coated with a thin layer of mud. The air temperature inside the cave was 12.7°C; the humidity was measured at 90%. Water temperature was 12°Cı pH was 7.2–7.7 and CO2 concentration was measured as 4 ppt. We found a few beetlesı woodlice and spiders and some colonies of bats in the Keeler cave.

Most of the more than 350 species of
Niphargus
are narrowly endemic. In accordance with common features of the genusı there are distinct differences separating populations in various geographic regions. A comparison of closely related species with the new species reveals these differences.

Compared to
N. khayami
ı the new species has a longer antenna I and longer gland cone in antenna IIı maxilla I inner plate with 2 distal setae while there are 6 in
N. khayami
ı and distal palp with only 3 apical setae vs 6 in
N. khayami
; gnathopod II propodus is trapezoidı vs rectangular in
N. khayami
; pereopods V–VII are longer compared to body length; lacinia mobilis in mandible is bifurcate; maxilliped has 3 small setae at base of palp nailı and posterior margin of distal article has no setae.

Antenna I is longer compared to
N. khwarizmi
; maxilla I inner plate has 2 distal setaeı vs 6 in
N. khwarizmi
; mandible Lacinia mobilis is bifurcate; and there are 5 E-setae on mandible palp article 3; maxilliped has 3 small setae at base of palp nailı and posterior margin of distal article without setae; pereopods V–VII are longer compared to body length; all segments of pleopods have long setae; distal article of uropod III exopod is short; no small spine is found on dorsal surface of telson.

The new species has also a longer antenna I and antenna II gland cone compared to
N. alisadri
. The other difference is in the maxillipedı with 3 small setae at base of palp nailı article 3 with no medial long seta in outer marginı and palp of terminal article with no seta in outer margin. Maxilla II inner plate has no lateral simple setae; gnathopods I and II have only 1 short supporting robust seta on inner surface of palmar corner; all segments of pleopods have long setae; distal article of uropod III exopodite is short. Telson has no spine on dorsal surface.

The new species can be distinguished from
N. kurdistanensis
by these differences: robust setae on outer plate of maxilla I have 2 or 3 lateral projections vs 0 or 1 in
N. kurdistanensis
; maxilla II has 1 subapical seta but
N. kurdistanensis
has 2 lateral simple setae instead; in gnathopods I and II robust setae in palmar corner of the propodus have no lateral projectionsı propodus of gnathopod I is slightly longer than broadı vs trapezoid and broader than long in
N. kurdistanensis
ı with 1 strong palmar robust seta and 2 small spiniform setaı vs 1 strong palmar robust setaı 1 supporting robust setaı and 2 robust setae with lateral projections on outer surface in
N. kurdistanensis
. Propodus of gnathopod II is as long as broadı vs broader than long in
N. kurdistanensis
ı palmar setae of gnathopods I and II are of moderate size (as long as or slightly longer than the width of the nail)ı while they are very long in
N. kurdistanensis
; uropod III is of moderate size (0.2 of body length) without distal setae on inner ramusı while it is long (almost 0.45 of body length) in
N. kurdistanensis
and has 3 robust distal setae on inner ramus; telson has 3 robust apical setae ( 2 in
N. kurdistanensis
); anterior margin of epimeral plates II–III are greatly rounded vs almost quadrilateral in
N. kurdistanensis
.

These comparisonsı indicating distinct differences between close species of the regionı shows that the newly described species
N. keeleri
can be quite easily distinguished from all other speciesı hence supporting our suggestion that it can be regarded as a good species.
